descriptions: Student cannot identify any accurate sources of information about mental, emotional, and social health.
Student identifies one source, but it is not entirely accurate or reliable.
Student identifies two sources, but their accuracy or reliability is questionable.
Student identifies three sources, with at least two being accurate and reliable.
Student identifies four sources, all of which are accurate and reliable.
Student identifies multiple (five or more) sources, all of which are highly accurate, reliable, and diverse in perspective.
Student demonstrates no understanding of the information provided by the sources.
Student demonstrates a limited understanding, with significant misconceptions or inaccuracies.
Student demonstrates some understanding, but struggles to explain key concepts or details.
Student demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of the information, accurately explaining most concepts.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding of the information, explaining concepts clearly and accurately with relevant details.
Student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of the information, explaining concepts with nuance, insight, and the ability to synthesize information from multiple sources.
Student cannot apply the information to real-life scenarios or personal well-being.
Student attempts to apply the information but does so ineffectively or inappropriately.
Student can apply the information to simple scenarios with guidance.
Student can apply the information to various scenarios, demonstrating an understanding of its relevance to personal well-being.
Student can effectively apply the information to complex scenarios, demonstrating critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
Student demonstrates exceptional ability to apply the information to real-life situations, advocating for mental health awareness and promoting positive change.
